page_description: Summarized visualization data and interpretations for India's macroeconomic indicators — GDP, inflation, expenditure composition, and income — based on National Accounts Statistics (MoSPI).

charts.title: Nominal vs Real GDP (Levels)
charts.description: Shows GDP at current and constant prices over time, comparing nominal and real output levels.
charts.summary: Both nominal and real GDP have grown steadily, but nominal GDP increases faster, reflecting inflation effects. A sharp post-2021 rebound is evident, with nominal GDP accelerating more strongly due to price inflation. The real GDP series flattens around 2019-21, consistent with pre-COVID slowdown and pandemic contraction.

charts.title: GDP Growth (Real & Nominal) vs CPI
charts.description: Compares annual GDP growth rates (real and nominal) with consumer inflation, illustrating how price changes influence nominal growth.
charts.summary: Real GDP growth remained around 5-8% for most years, with a deep contraction in 2020-21 followed by a sharp recovery. Nominal GDP growth consistently exceeds real growth, driven by inflation as shown by the rising CPI index. The widening post-2021 gap indicates that a significant portion of nominal growth reflects price effects rather than pure output expansion.

charts.title: Expenditure Composition (% of NGDP)
charts.description: Breaks down GDP by major expenditure components to show relative contributions of consumption, investment, and net exports.
charts.summary: Private consumption (PFCE) dominates GDP, averaging 55-60% of total expenditure. Government spending (GFCE) is stable near 10%, and investment (GFCF) contributes roughly 30%. Net exports remain negative throughout, reflecting a persistent trade deficit that narrows slightly after 2020. India's growth remains consumption-led with gradual recovery in investment post-pandemic.

charts.title: Per Capita Income (Nominal)
charts.description: Shows the trend of nominal per-capita income over time, reflecting average income levels before adjusting for inflation.
charts.summary: Nominal per-capita income has risen steadily from about ₹70,000 in 2011-12 to over ₹2 lakh by 2023-24, nearly tripling in twelve years. The dip in 2020-21 corresponds to the COVID-19 shock, followed by a strong recovery. Inflation-adjusted gains would be smaller, but nominally, India's income growth trajectory remains upward and resilient.

charts.title: Distribution: Growth Rates (Real vs Nominal)
charts.description: Summarizes the distribution and variability of real and nominal GDP growth rates across the observation period.
charts.summary: Real GDP growth shows a median around 7% with moderate volatility and a pandemic-driven outlier near -6%. Nominal GDP growth centers near 10-11% but with a wider spread, reflecting inflation cycles. The upward shift of the nominal distribution relative to the real confirms that inflation systematically lifts nominal growth rates.

overall_insight: From 2011-12 to 2023-24, India's nominal GDP and per-capita income have expanded sharply, with inflation accounting for part of the nominal rise. Real growth remains strong on average but shows pandemic disruption. The economy is predominantly consumption-driven, with investment recovering post-2020. Inflation (CPI) trends closely track the widening gap between nominal and real measures, underlining the role of price dynamics in headline GDP growth.
